patterns: How can I share my file with my team?
Which tools can I use to collaborate with others?
how can we work on the same file together ?
how can the team be on the same page remotely
how to work in a co-working or other shared space
responses: Using Google Suite for its file sharing is a great way to collaborate with your team. No matter where your employees are, you rest assured that your team has access to vital data, on any device with internet access. With automatic saving and the templates feature, your team is always on the same page.

OneDrive for Business, especially in combination with Office 365, gives you great cloud benefits, including security and integrity in file backups. With advanced encryption and compliance, you never have to worry about your data security.

Like its competitors, Dropbox for Business gives you collaboration and syncing tools that meet your business needs and help you maintain the structure of your business, with admin levels and controls, device approvals and other benefits.

Skype for Business gives you the ability to video conference with up to 250 people, even if the attendants donâ€™t have the tool. In combination with Office 365, you can start video conference from Office software, like Word and PowerPoint
Slack is an instant messaging tool designed for keeping workflow on track. With channels and direct messaging capabilities, communication is simplified and prioritized.

Ring Central for Business is another popular tool for video conferencing, with good international service, multilanguage support and more. Desktop sharing also proves useful when teams are collaborating.

patterns: Network is slow on my laptop
I have slow internet on my phone
my internet is not moving fast
what can I do with internet connection
responses: The problem could be faulty wires or an overcrowded network.
Depending on your router, you will need to change channels or move the antennas around to see if it helps
If your speed is still slow after testing your speed online, itâ€™s best to speak with your ISP to confirm the issue or see if you need to change packages

If your Wi-Fi speed is slow no matter where you are, try plugging a laptop into your modem directly and test your internet speed using a site like speedtest.net. If speeds are still down, the problem is likely with your internet connection, not your router. Contact your ISP.

You can follow the same troubleshooting tips mentioned above for this problem. The problem could be faulty wires or an overcrowded network.Depending on your router, you will need to change channels or move the antennas around to see if it helps. Similar issues can also impair TV service without proper antenna installation.If your speed is still slow after testing your speed online, itâ€™s best to speak with your ISP to confirm the issue or see if you need to change packages.

If your Wi-Fi speed is slow no matter where you are, try plugging a laptop into your modem directly and test your internet speed using a site like speedtest.net. If speeds are still down. Contact your ISP.If thatâ€™s not the issue, it could be that your current wireless channel is overcrowded by your devices or by those of other nearby networks. Consider changing the channel on your router in your router settings. Each router brand does that a little differently, though.If that doesnâ€™t help, performing a factory reset on your router and setting it up again may help.

patterns: I can't connect to the internet
Internet of my pc is disconnecting
my network device can't connect to Wi-Fi
my phone is not connecting to Wi-Fi
what is wrong with my phone's internet
responses: Make sure Wi-Fi is on.Then turn it off and on again to reconnect.Make sure Airplane mode is off.Then turn it on and off again to reconnect.Press your phone's power button for a few seconds. Then, on your screen, tap Restart .If you don't see 'Restart' press refresh and hold the power button for about 30 seconds, until your phone restarts.

If your WiFi connection failed, choose the 'forget network' option in your device. Discover the Wi-Fi again and re-enter the credentials and try connecting.Internet issues in the router could cause such troubles.Restarting the router will allow it to look for its newly assigned IP address. If the problem occurred due to a crowded network, taking this step should solve it.

If youâ€™re running Windows 10 or 11, search for 'troubleshooting' and open the result, which should be Identify and Repair Network Issues. That will go through a series of diagnostics that may restore connectivity. On MacOS, you can run Wireless Diagnostics. Hold the Options key and click the AirPort (Wi-Fi) icon on the menu bar.If none of that works, consider rebooting the device.
